5909: MacOS/UNIX filenames are case sensitive, Windows filenames are not. A folder containing both "ABC.TXT" and "abc.txt" can be synced to a UNIX machine without problems, but when synced to a Windows machine, only one of the two files will survive.MEGA imposes no restrictions on filenames - they can contain characters that are incompatible with the operating system, such as : or *. These will be rewritten as %xx on the local side and converted back to the original character when synced back. The Windows Explorer also has trouble with a number of seemingly innocuous file and folder names - "con.doc", for example, would not be accessible (to understand why, you have to be a geek or a veteran, or both). If you encounter such a situation, simply rename the file on the cloud side. Foreign characters in filenames are fully supported.MEGAsync supports fairly deep folder structures (MEGA itself is limited to a maximum of 63 levels) and very long pathnames (up to 32,000 characters under Windows). Unfortunately, most Windows software (including the Explorer) is unable to access files whose path is longer than 260 characters.

6295: Copyright -  is a legal concept, enacted by most governments, giving the creator of an original work exclusive rights to it, usually for a limited time. Generally, it is "the right to copy", but also gives the copyright holder the right to be credited for the work, to determine who may adapt the work to other forms, who may perform the work, who may financially benefit from it, and other related rights. It is a form of intellectual property (like the patent, the trademark, and the trade secret) applicable to any expressible form of an idea or information that is substantive and discrete.

6300: You can share any subtree of your cloud drive with friends, family or coworkers. Invitation is by e-mail address. Invitees who do not have an account yet will receive an e-mail notification with a signup link. Alternatively, you can create a public link to any of your folders and export the folder-specific crypto key, making it accessible without a MEGA account. It is then your responsibility to securely transmit the folder key to the recipient(s).
6302: Select a folder you want to share with your colleague - right click that folder and select 'Sharing'. Enter your friends email address and permission level in the pop up window that appears.  There are three access levels: Read-only, read/write (files can be added, but not deleted), and full (files can be added and deleted).
6303: If your colleague does not have a MEGA account, they will receive an invite email in their email inbox to create their own free account.
6304: If they already have an account with MEGA, your email address will appear under their 'Contacts' in their Mega account and the shared folder can be found in the 'Incoming shares' section. They will also receive a Notification inside their account.
6306: Please double check the each user has each other's email ID added to 'Contacts'. If a 'share' from a new contact hasn't automatically added the email ID this share came from into 'Contacts' please make sure you add that email ID manually (Contact - Add Contact).
6307: If you added an e-mail address that did not have an account yet, you need to be online at least once after the recipient completes the signup process so that you can encrypt the share secret to his newly created public key.
6308: Right-clicking on any folder in your Cloud Drive and selecting 'Reload' also helps with recent updates.
6309: Simply right click on a folder in your Cloud Drive and select Sharing. You will see all people that currently have access (and access level) to the shared folder.
6310: Right click on the person and click the remove symbol 'x' option from the menu.
6311: To leave an incoming share go to 'Incoming shares', right-click on the folder and select 'Leave share' from the menu.
6312: Shared folders (outgoing) in your Cloud Drive have a special icon with three silhouettes on the folder.
6313: Your incoming shares are visible in 'Incoming shares' section.
6314: No. Folder shares are non-transitive to prevent any unauthorised re-distribution.
6315: First of all, a word of caution: The cryptographic security of your files depends on the confidentiality of the associated encryption keys. Make sure that you transmit them via protected channels only! Standard e-mail, for example, is not good enough.
6317: Select a file you want to share with your friend - right click and select 'Get link'.  A pop up window will appear. Copy and paste this 'File Link' and 'File Key' into a new email (for increased security separate file link and file key into two messages. Sending both the Link and the key together is not very secure. You can email it to your friend via secure channels.
6318: When the recipient receives your email and clicks on your link, a Mega window will appear and give them options:
6322: Right-click on the folder that already has a link generated and select 'Sharing'. In the 'Sharing' interface you will see an existing 'Link' with a switch set on 'ON'. Simply click on the 'ON' switch and drag it across the field to 'OFF'.
6323: To change a link to the same data:

6538: MacOS/UNIX filenames are case sensitive, Windows filenames are not. A folder containing both "ABC.TXT" and "abc.txt" can be synced to a UNIX machine without problems, but when synced to a Windows machine, only one of the two files will survive.
6539: MEGA imposes no restrictions on filenames - they can contain characters that are incompatible with the operating system, such as : or *. These will be rewritten as %xx on the local side and converted back to the original character when synced back. The Windows Explorer also has trouble with a number of seemingly innocuous file and folder names - "con.doc", for example, would not be accessible (to understand why, you have to be a geek or a veteran, or both). If you encounter such a situation, simply rename the file on the cloud side. Foreign characters in filenames are fully supported.

6554: MEGAsync is a program that synchronises your local folders with your MEGA Cloud folders.
6555: This means however it will also synchronise mistakes made in your local folder, for example, if you accidentally overwrite a file in your local folder, that file will be updated in your MEGA account, hence it shouldn't be relied upon to backup live data.
6556: The best way of using MEGAsync for backups would be to create a local "Backups" folder on your computer and use a proper backup program (or even a batch file or script) to create a backup and save the backup file in this folder, which will then be synchronised to your MEGA account.
6557: Using this method will also allow you to create multiple backup files.
6558: For example using the date of the backup file, eg 22-10-14.zip, 23-10-14.zip, 24-10-14.zip, etc.
6559: These files will all be synchronised to your MEGA account and when you remove the oldest backup file from your computer to conserve space, it will also be removed from your MEGA account.
6561: 1. Create a local backups folder, eg, c:\backups
6562: 2. Setup a backup program or batch file/script to periodically create a
6563: backup of your files to c:\backups for example the end of the day, or week.
6564: 3. Set MEGAsync to synchronise c:\backups to your MEGA account
6565: Data uploaded to MEGA is stored on at least two international data storage servers. We currently have servers in New Zealand, Germany, Luxembourg and The Netherlands. We plan to add servers in Canada later this year. For most recent update click here: https://mega.co.nz/#blog_21
6566: However always keep redundant copies of important files, online and offline. Although we keep each file in at least two locations, there is no guarantee against multiple concurrent failures and repeated
6568: We provide for user controlled encryption (UCE) where you, the user, control the keys. The UCE implementation is open source, and we invite and encourage the community to scrutinise it and provide feedback.
6569: We believe that this approach is much safer than storing your data on a provider with server-side encryption where the ISP controls the keys or, worse, no encryption at all - if, for example, MEGA user files were suddenly accessible without a password due to a programming error, they would be unreadable without the user-controlled decryption keys.

6643: When you 'Create Account' with Mega (https://mega.nz/#register), the pop up on the page will tell you to expect a 'Confirmation Email' and you should go to your email inbox and look for a 'MEGA Activation' email.  In this 'Confirmation' email, you click on the confirmation link which takes you to Mega again to put in your password for the second time so that you can authenticate your account.  If successful, you are taken to your Mega account displaying 'Cloud Drive'.
6645: If you haven’t received the email to confirm/activate your account, please check your junk mail folder and spam filters at your email address.
6646: If you still can’t locate the email, you might try to re-register using the original email address.  If the confirmation email for this registration does not appear in any of your email folders, then we suggest that you contact your ISP to determine if there is a 'block' on Mega emails.  Alternatively you may need to sign up using a different email ID.
6647: If you are getting the warning message "Incorrect password / email ID" - that appears when the password you entered at the point of registration and the password you try to enter to validate and confirm your account don't match.
6648: We suggest to start registration again with the same email address and write the password down somewhere secure to validate it later. Try to make your password longer so it is not easily guessed. Combine upper and lower case letters, add special characters (we don't limit any!). Do not use names or dictionary words. Also do not use copy & paste function while creating your account - please make sure you type your password in each time when registering.
6649: We also strongly discourage users to use password generators as your password is also going to be your unique encryption key.
6651: If the activation link you have received after signing up at Mega does not work when you click on it try to copy and paste the link directly into your browser; check for any extra white space that your email client might have entered.
6652: If you still cannot activate your account try to re-register for a MEGA account with the same email address or sign up using a different email address to receive a new confirmation link.

6682: The privacy and security you get with browser based end to end encryption can take it's toll on speed as due to not all browsers provide complete HTML5 support. MEGA's users get to enjoy the privacy of their data with our User Controlled Encryption (UCE) mechanism - the only storage provider on the market offering this level of security and privacy.
6683: The speed of downloads/uploads is dependent on the state and speed of your computer, software, operating systems and versions and your ISP provider. With Mega, you can control the 'speed' of downloads or uploads, depending on your priorities in 'My Account' - 'Transfer Settings'. You can try to maximize your upload performance by disabling the 'Upload Speed Limit' as well.
6684: We do default the 'Upload Speed Limit' to enabled as many routers do not prioritize smaller packets in case of link congestion, resulting in your inbound traffic being severely affected when your outbound link is full. We therefore measure your available outbound bandwidth during the initial ten seconds of an upload and then keep at least 10% of it unused.
6685: The speed tests such as speedtest.net are great when you want to determine if your router or ISP has issues – you know what your speed ‘should’ be and this test indicates if there is an issue somewhere along the ‘lines’. However the result from speed test does not have a direct relation to speed with MEGA. The speed test will indicate whether everything is working right from the users or ISP’s end however there are other factors to take into consideration. Such as international peering issues (internet as a whole is currently experiencing: http://www.internetpulse.com/); the state of users computer (whether your software is up to date, whether your HDD and browser are clogged by temp or cached data or fragmented…); transfer speed also depends which server we are storing the data on.
6686: To sum it up - your Pro account's increased bandwidth does not have any relation to 'speed' however greater bandwidth may improve the speed of your traffic indirectly.

6714: In order for any of the following to make sense, I urge you to get into MEGA, and start testing for yourself, and see how what i am about to describe can apply!
6715: OK, the way to do this :
6716: Firstly, the leader of this project, or the file administrator would set up an account which would be considered the MASTER account - This can just be a normal Free account, or Pro (https://mega.nz/#pro) depending on your storage requirements.
6717: 1 - Each other user must have an account set up with MEGA.nz - They are Free :)
6718: 2 - You need to add each of their email IDs to your master account's Contacts.
6719: 3 - In your master account, it is up to you to set up the 'hierarchy' as described. E.g. you would create a different folder unique to each user, you could call it by their name.
6720: 4 - Once you have set up the 'hierarchy' to reach the level that you need uploaded to (e.g. User/ Event and sub folder, Users name)
6721: you can then 'right click' select sharing, and assign that user with FULL ACCESS!
6722: 5 - From here, this folder is effectively synced on both accounts, any modifications are visible at both accounts instantly!
6723: You then load files into that folder, and they will be visible at the other users account too, listed under their 'Incoming Shares'
6724: Then are also notifications to alert all users with access to that folder, of any recent activities such as new files added, removed etc.
6725: FULL Access allows both the master account, and the receiving account with full permissions to that folder. Each user could upload, download, modify and erase any content in that folder. The other permission levels are Read Only (no adding, no deleting) and Read and Write (you can add but not delete).
6726: -- You may want to set up your master account, and set up a dummy account for yourself too, and start familiarizing, and the above will make sense! (Obviously with following above steps to share/bridge)
